review_title: Amazon is a well known and respected company around the world.
pros: For integration, peace, life, prosperous, and  development.
cons: Language communication, employer's requirement, the weather, lack of recognition of foreign credentials and experience

pros:
Fast and easy recruitment scheme.

Unskilled labour so very easy to secure a job there.

40 hour work week, 4 days per week - my shift pattern was Sunday - Wednesday 7am - 5:30am.

Paid an additional £2 per hour during coronavirus peak, also offered a £500 bonus for a 1 month completion in July 2020.
cons:
An enormous company so very impersonal (managers rarely know your names).

They monitor everything - I have been asked to verify why my "away from station" time was over 8 minutes (it was because I went to the toilet and the warehouse is huge so takes ages to walk there. 

Management style is pretty annoying - productivity is pushed massively but there is no incentive to hit targets or work well. Often managers come over to tell you how to "improve" your productivity and in doing so, reduces your productivity. Advice often comes across as condescending for such a simple job. 

The two x 30 min breaks you are allowed get timed very strictly which is annoying as it can take you 10 minutes to walk from your station to the cantine / lunch areas. 

You're not allowed to sit down in the warehouse, this means even if there is no work to do you have to stand for at least 9.5 hours per day. 

Its hard physical work and very boring, wouldn't recommend it as a long term job.

review_title: Good pay rate but very physical labour
job_title: Permanent Part-Time Associate in Stoughton, MA
pros:
- Decent pay.
- Labor: most roles and very physical, even though there is a 15-min break. You may have to constantly walk or lift heavy weights (up to 40 something lbs) for 4+ hours. But you'll get used to it.
- Benefits: sometimes they give away stuff to motivate employees.
cons:
- People: many associates are very nice and hard-working people who take their jobs seriously, but there are also slackers (while you try hard to keep your pace, they just stand there talking and take their time). Lots of times the supervisors don't see it.
- Hours: on paper each shift lasts for 4hrs, but in reality 80-90% of the time you will work 4.5-5hrs/shift (you sign agreement on contract, so you can't refuse). And they'll only announce it once you're at work which means if you need a pick-up, you have to use break-time to make a call. If you need a fixed schedule, you may want to consider another job.

review_title: Data-driven and Disciplined but Bureaucratic Approach for Building Products
job_title: Senior Technical Product Manager in Austin, TX
pros:
I work in Last Mile Tech on the mobile application used by 350K+ drivers worldwide across dozens of Amazon programs
- Strong compensation (salary, sign-on bonus, stock)
- WW user base at unbelievable scale (and growing)
- Strong belief and application of leadership principles
- Mostly data-driven decision making
cons:
- Lots of bureaucracy in decision making. Limited local ownership. Even small changes need 3 levels of management approval. Does not operate like a startup, despite the marketing.
- 50% of time spent on status reports and program management rather than product definition
- Challenges are centered around the horrible legacy app architecture and a gordian knot of dependencies with dozens of other teams; Limited time spent on actual innovation.
- Prone to major org changes every 12 months

job_title: Strategic Account Manager in London, England
pros: Lovely team mates. Great camaraderie and support within teams.
cons:
My Amazon experience was an extremely toxic and draining one. I've worked for various media companies before, both small and large, but have never experienced the working environment that is Amazon. 

The pressure put on employees to meet targets and goals is highly unattainable and will drive you mad. Work/life balance was non-existent, working till 8/9pm in the office was a regular occurrence, with no thanks. A huge blame culture within the company and a very hierarchical management structure. 

Minimum support from managers, mico-management, and huge amounts of internal politics. The worst company I've worked for and would tell anyone to stay away from working in their head office. Do not be seduced by high salaries, stocks, and sign on bonuses (which they'll snatch back from you right away if you leave within a year). If you value your mental health and personal life, please go for a smaller, more supportive and positive company if you can.

pros:
Friendly well informed co workers. Supervisors are very knowledgeable and patient. If you’re willing to learn they are happy to spend the time to teach you the methods used to complete your assigned tasks.

The lead at the Amazon Oak Creek WI facility is a Master Electrician Inspector. If you pay close attention and have an eye for detail, he can and will willingly share a wealth of knowledge with you.. Priceless

Con workers are extremely cool and easy a pleasure to work with. The lead recruiter Bernadette, clearly does an exceptional job at hand picking the best of the best people.
The entire crew is just very cool very professional positive people always ready and willing to jump in help with any tasks needed.
cons:
I enjoy what I do and enjoy the field I’m in here. However, it is a job it is work. As with any job there are times where you may get frustrated with a particular equipment problem that presents a brand new challenge you haven’t yet seen or had to deal with.

Patience goes a long way and communicating with your co workers and peers is crucial to resolving these types of situations as quickly as possible while still maintaining a level of professionalism in your craftsmanship. 

When equipment goes down, Amazons employees may be at a stand still. The way Amazon works is if one section stops moving, then the next 4 employees can’t do their job, which means the next 8 people can’t do their job, which means the next 22 employees can’t do their job.

Basically, when there’s an equipment failure, you have about 15 minutes before you have up to 60 Amazon employees that can’t do there job and things come to a halt.

It’s not a huge deal, but speed accuracy and doing the job right the first time is crucial to keeping Amazons employees moving. If you’re the type to cut corners and freeze up or let emotion get the best of you under pressure this position may not be for you.

If you’re cool calm focused and detail orientated have a positive professional attitude and are open minded willing to learn you’ll do just fine.

job_title: Senior Human Resources Assistant in Shepherdsville, KY
pros: I started as a level 1 associate in 2014. I worked on the floor for almost a year. I worked extremely hard therefore I only worked in a direct function for maybe a month. From there I was asked to do multiple support functions. Within my first 3 months I could do anything in the building. I was encouraged by my HRBP to apply for an HR entry position. I held that role for 6 months and was asked to apply for a Sr HR Asst. Role. If you are willing to put in the effort and the work and set aside your feelings on alot of this, you can build your career in no time at all.
cons: Unfortunately working in HR in a fast paced, quick turnaround job like this. It comes with its mental toll. Some people can set all of their feelings aside and fully commit. I found after 5 years in the Senior role that it wasn't for me I'm that environment. I love helping people and care far too much. After working on the floor you grow to care for alot of people and seeing people you care about come and go so often and sometimes having to be the bad guy can take its toll. Aside from this, which I feel doesn't reflect on the company rather my own person. I loved it.

review_title: Not bad for medium-term experience gain
job_title: FC Associate I in Dallas, TX
pros:
- As long as you have a pulse, you're hired. There isn't even an interview process, nor do they take your resume. As long as you show up to orientation, you're golden. 

- Flexible schedules. I prefer a reliable set-in-stone schedule, myself, but they also had an option to choose what shifts you wanted from a pool. 

- Great way to stay in shape and lose some weight. This is more or less a positive outlook on all the manual labor you'll be doing

- Decent health coverage. There are some pretty decent plans for coverage all around. 

- Good experience booster. Because of the ease of access in getting the job and the simplicity of the roles, this is a pretty decent resume booster!

- Time-off flexibility. Amazon will probably be the only job I have where I can just leave whenever I want (so long as I have enough paid time off or time off otherwise to cover it)

- Discount. You get a 10% discount off Amazon-distributed AND produced items so that's kinda cool (*up to $100 in savings).
cons:
- Isolation. Job gets a little lonely sometimes--especially when we're busy. 

-- Soreness. You are on your feet all day, constantly bending your knees. It's easy at first, but doing it long enough really aches your muscles. Make sure you go to bed at a decent hour and drink plenty of water before, during, and after your shift. This job will drain you.

--Alarms. So there's all this warehouse noise going on that makes it a little hard to hear sometimes, but that's to be expected. But when the main conveyor parts go off, wooh boy. You'd think you're working in a nuclear facility! They seem to go off everywhere sometimes

-- Boredom. Kinda goes hand-in-hand with Isolation. This job is VERY UN-stimulating. I'm a picker. I scan items, toss them in bin, press the button to verify the transition, and then rinse and repeat. Try to preoccupy your mind with something .

-- MET. Depending on your shift, you could be called in for mandatory extra time at any moment and that can get annoying. 

--Techincal issues. There are annoying technical glitches that happen with my station, sometimes the pods with the items arrive slow, and sometimes amnesty stops my area to fix something and all these issues stall my rate. While the latter two are out of managements control, some of the stations on my floor feel like they've been neglected. Sometimes the buttons don't work, the tote-lifter falts for whatever reason, the release break that holds the totes back gets stuck, and there's even been a couple of times where the problem couldn't even be identified.

pros: Competitive culture throughout partnered with direct engagement with associates is great environment for those that enjoy working with others.
cons:
Amazon has an online organization chart we use called phonetool. Cool thing about this application is you can add adons that will showcase more data for viewers. One I've added has been job tenure & roles so I can see when looking at peers and other Amazonians profiles. A very common trend that is too apparent to overlook in the amount of time employees of color spend in their roles compared to white counterparts. I literally have AAs who came into the company as Tier 1s that have progressed faster than myself and other black counterparts whom come in with a degrees and as entry level management. Statically speaking on average black employees spend 1.5 -2 years in their roles prior to progression when the average progression within the company is 1 - 1.5 years. 
So being a white male or female you can literally have no formal secondary education and work within amazon and progress faster than a black employee with a degree that was hired into management. I have personally worked in the company for 3 years with nothing but high marks from all my direct managers with very minimum to no negative feedback and have been given many hoops to jump through. Example I was told at one site I had to learn inbound and outbound before coming a level 5 manager to only find out I had level 7 seniors that had progressed and only been in 1 side of the business their entire career. Also noticed their is certainly a "boys club" if you are liked by senior team I've seen people pulled to positions that were never posted and promoted when being in the role for only a few months. It's extremely frustrating to work in an environment that says they promote growth & not having a glass ceiling and seeing blatant trends of discrimination.

You’ll have to work harder at establishing trust for a not-yet-known label, especially compared to older, better-known brands.
A lot of product quality is out of your hands and you’ll be relying on your supplier/manufacturer to make good pieces.

job_title: FC Associate I in Glendale, CA
pros:
• Flexible work schedule
• Super easy to get hired. 
> Background check, drug test, and you're in. Job hiring events are en mass.

• Casual dress code
• W-2 job protections 
> i.e., unemployment insurance
cons:
• Flexible work schedule
> Because of the high turn over rate, and the constant influx of new hires, it made it very difficult to pick up shifts if you were not on the platform at 18:00 on the dot when the new shifts would be released.
• No hazard pay
• Difficult to transfer departments when applying to other positions better suited for you via their public job board
• Unable to access the internal job board due to no terminal access at the job site; no VPN access provided.
• Amazon wants robots out of humans.
• Every man/woman for themselves type of mentality.
> Doesn't help that there is a high turn over rate.
• No employee parking
• No in-store discount for food/groceries

pros:
Set schedule

Besides that I can't think of any. Amazon is truly a terrible place to work, at least on the warehouse level. The benefits used to be good but with competitors now amending their benefits packages, Amazon is no longer leading in this department. So do yourself a favor and work elsewhere.
cons:
-You're just a number.
-Apathetic leaders, who don't really care about their associates 
-Long, depressing hours.
-Zero chances to get onto day shift (at lease in my building)
-Managers do not follow company wide policies and as such our work place is dangerous with items falling off the shelves and onto AAs. Any complaints to leadership are ignored and any action used to fix the MODS is smoke and mirrors.
-A tone deaf work campaign about mental health while Amazon's policys and procedures directly contribute to the mental health struggles of their employees.
-Broken down equipment and tools... that have yet to been replaced despite these being problem issues for at least a year
-Rude, ignorant employees that don't care about their work, leading to low quality work being pushed out.
-If you're a Tier 1 expect for the managers and PAs to speak to you in a patronizing matter. no vest=no respect. I remember my rate was low because it was a slow day and my manager at the time said something. I said there is no work on the line and he laughed sarcastically saying "look at all the work" and walked away. Don't see how something that could negatively impact my livelihood is funny esp during the pandemic but it's fitting considering how the managers have to have some degree of sociopathy to work there.
-Most managers are clueless because they get substandard training and most of them don't have relevant experience, just a college degree. Amazon says it promotes from within but it's an open secret that it's easier to just apply externally if you want to move up.
-Related to the above point, there are managers who do not know the policies and procedures of amazon... 
-Managers never stay in one position for more than 6 months. I have gone through at least 10 managers since starting at this company. 
-Switched over to an offsite "HR Investigation" system and they have been useless. Dealt with numerous instances of workplace harassment since the switch and decided to no longer report any more instances as this new system is useless.
-Raises are not proportionate to the amount of work that this job requires. 
-And neither are the wages. Expect to work more than 40 hours a week because they pay so little (going back to the tone deaf mental health campaign, maybe if people didn't have to work 60 hours to have a livable wage they would be happier?)

job_title: Software Development Engineer I in Boulder, CO
pros: Amazon’s leadership principles are legit and are applied every day as part of the decision making framework. Everyone is constantly trying to replace subjective opinions with objective data-derived opinions and as a result even and L4 SDE can influence a design discussion involving an L7 Principal engineer. Work is structured around teams and everyone on your team including your manager is there to support you and share their knowledge. Amazon is solving huge problems and the work is super interesting.
cons: You need to be ready to vocalize your opinions / doubts / needs as an employee. If you don’t advocate for yourself you might end up working on less interesting stuff, getting sidelined in design discussions, and feeling less like a part of the team. So if you are someone who likes to put their head down and work solo this probably is not for you.

- Surrounded by top engineers

cons:
- On call rotation can be taxing (can vary depending on team)
- Heavy workload
- Large scale events can be stressful
- Work life balance was not great for me
- Expected to ramp up quickly and early on despite not being exposed to a lot of the processes and perform at the same levels as more tenured team members regardless of past experience
- Budget constraints from higher up can effect the team
- If you don't reach the "bar" you will be notified and be put on PIP
- This bar is not very clear at every level
- Even if the engineers are on your side at the end of the day the manager decides if you stay or not

job_title: Senior Program Manager in Seattle, WA

cons: See "Pros" + Amazon will sell you a "Dream Opportunity"; don't be fooled by their leadership principles/rigorous interview process to uphold their hiring high standards facade or what seems like an amazing offer and compensation package - Amazon knows how to get you in the door (they're the biggest e-comm business for a reason; they know how to sell) but they don't know how to keep you. job_title: Senior Content Writer in Seattle, WA
pros: Flexibility in working from home.
cons:
My department was very much a "cult of youth" culture. People just a few years out of college were given large teams to build and manage. This was poorly considered and just was disastrous to the team on so many levels. Yet it happens.

Others with 15+ years in the industry and who have families were dismissed as having little to offer and excluded from team discussions and team social events, where a lot of networking takes place.

Inclusivity and work-life balance are giving a lot of air time, but it seems like no one really knows how to put it into practice. Ageism is rampant. Regularly staying up to 2 AM to meet deadlines is worn like a badge of honor.

The culture really needs to mature, but it seems like it just doesn't know how to.

pros: Easy in - have a pulse, pass a drug test; this includes ex-convicts, non-discriminatory. Easy pay, health and dental affordable, tons of exercise.
cons: Work began fine, plenty of hype, bells and talk about putting the customers first. Within 6-8 weeks, the reality can no longer hide, its only about cranking out the shipments ASAP. Management verbally states that they want quality, then they come to see you on the line and yell about how you need to be faster. Packing boxes as quickly as possible. Trying to be careful and use the bubbles "dunnage" for fragile items = "you're taking too much time!" "Hurry up". People rewarded do not use the dunnage bubbles, do not send back items to QC which are damaged, they just ship them out and make the numbers.

review_title: Amazon takes advantage of people that are in dire need of money.
pros: quick pay-- but not paid enough so no pros to working at this slime ball of a place
cons:
1. Terrible management
2. Broken machines
3. 1-2 sec tote exchange, 7-sec average to remove the item from the pod with the product- put it into a tote- then hit the button to assign an item to the tote. if you do not meet these expectations then they will constantly tell you how awful of a worker you are and how you need to improve asap or you will be written up. 
4. My manager tried to blackmail me into improving my rate, told me how tired i looked every morning, micromanaged me constantly, and eventually drove me to quit. My PA told me my calves were too small to be a tote runner. Old men//all men stare at you if you are a girl (cover-up) 
5. Terrible on your body. My friend told me he has a constant crack in his back from picking for a -year-. 
6. Presented a video about wellness & if you are experiencing these symptoms then report them to your manager. So I did and when I went to "wellness" which is kinda like medical, they told me to take ibuprofen and slap some Biofreeze on it-- then didn't provide me anything. Useless
7. Offered "free" shoes-- they are free because no one wants to buy them. terrible reviews. mine rubbed the hell out of the back of my heel and made my feet ache. Offer the shitties candy and free snacks-- the cheapest thing to make it look like they kinda care. 
8. You must run to the bathroom. if it is being cleaned or has a line-- too bad u have 5 minutes and if you aren't back then u get "time-off-task" which affects ur rate- don't worry, your manager will ask where you were during that time & ask why u weren't working. 

Don't work at amazon--- they only have staff because they are hiring & taking advantage of people that need the money to put food on their family's tables or to pay rent, etc.

review_title: You get out what you put in
job_title: Program Manager II in Seattle, WA
pros:
- resume booster
- learn a lot
- everything is easier after Amazon

Things got a lot easier when I drew boundaries and only did 40 hours of work. When you logically piece together why you can’t take on more projects, there is work life balance. Amazon is also very good at giving potential a chance, letting people transfer job functions or teams within the company with ease (at the L4+ levels).
cons:
- internal pay structure sucks
- promotions are heavily contingent on whether c-executives like you or not

I know this is very dependent on management structure, but when you have transferred 3 times and encountered the same things even though the teams are vastly different, there is a systemic issue with how Amazon selects upper and middle management.

review_title: It's Good if you are willing to work VERY hard.
pros:
- good salary
- great office
- lots of autonomy, definitely feel like you are making a difference from the start. 
- great chance to gain experience working with a variety of brands/categories
- work with very smart and talented people
cons:
- very technically difficult job, need to be competent with numbers and data. Need to be a very fast learner of you will get left behind.
- poor work life balance, the job is always on your mind. 
- not very good training, very much thrown in at the deep end and expected to be an expert in many things. Will often be asked to watch outdated online training videos.
